data.body:
I am using FileBeat to ship Varnish logs to Logstash, and the log file I'm monitoring is heavily written to. If I 'tail' the file, I get a constant stream of records.

My varnish log is set to rotate every hour, using hourly `logrotate`:

	/var/log/varnish/*.log {
		rotate 4
		size 1k
		dateext
		dateformat .%Y%m%d.%s
		missingok
		notifempty
		sharedscripts
		nocompress
		postrotate
			/bin/kill -HUP `cat /var/run/varnishlog.pid 2>/dev/null` 2> /dev/null || true
			/bin/kill -HUP `cat /var/run/varnishncsa.pid 2>/dev/null` 2> /dev/null || true
		endscript
	}

My filebeat log however, just says:

    2016-02-10T14:58:14Z DBG  Start next scan
    2016-02-10T14:58:14Z DBG  scan path /var/log/varnish/*.log
    2016-02-10T14:58:14Z DBG  Check file for harvesting: /var/log/varnish/varnishncsa.log
    2016-02-10T14:58:14Z DBG  Update existing file for harvesting: /var/log/varnish/varnishncsa.log
    2016-02-10T14:58:14Z DBG  Not harvesting, file didn't change: /var/log/varnish/varnishncsa.log

Here's my filebeat.yml

	filebeat:
	  spool_size: 10000
	  idle_timeout: 10s
	  prospectors:
		-
		  ignore_older: 8h
		  type: log
		  document_type: varnish
		  paths:
			- "/var/log/varnish/*.log"

	output:
	  logstash:
		hosts: ["logstash:5044", "elastic1:5044", "elastic2:5044", "elastic3:5044"]
		loadbalance: true
		bulk_max_size: 500
		max_retries: -1

	shipper:

	logging:
	  level: debug
	  to_files: true
	  to_syslog: false

	  files:
		path: /var/log
		name: filebeat.log
		keepfiles: 7
		files.rotateeverybytes: 10485760


I'm using a snapshot 1.1.1 release from https://download.elastic.co/beats/filebeat/filebeat-1.1.1-SNAPSHOT-x86_64.rpm.

If I restart the service, it'll work again.
data.title: Monitoring a busy file, but getting "Not harvesting, file didn't change"

data.body:
A cmd-line flag or configuration option to have filebeat exit once all prospectors have reached end-of-file would help support integration testing efforts.  The use case is to start filebeat with a known set of files, ship them to a test instance of logstash, and then compare the results.  There are some workarounds I can think of:

- kill filebeat after a set time
- grep filebeat output for "no events to publish"

While not important for my use case, might want to think about exit codes, like what to return if unable to ship all events.
data.title: Support a "batch" mode

data.body:
All beats have a default ES mapping template file. I added a very basic one as part of #65, but we should consider using one more similar with what Logstash provides by default: https://github.com/logstash-plugins/logstash-output-elasticsearch/blob/master/lib/logstash/outputs/elasticsearch/elasticsearch-template.json

One thing to note is that Filebeat/libbeat currently doesn't have the capability of filling the `.raw` fields so that part is lost if going directly to ES.
data.title: Discuss template file for filebeat

data.body: Currently the shutdown process of filebeat is not fully predictable. The implementation should be improved with WaitGroups. For more details see: https://github.com/elastic/filebeat/pull/75/files#r41322074
data.title: Improve filebeat shutdown process

data.body:
I think the persisted registry should contain data on all files that Filebeat's prospector encounters, not just the ones from which an event is published.

Consider this situation, I have many old, large log files that Filebeat sees but ignores. I stop Filebeat. Some service decides to write to one of those old log files. I restart Filebeat and now Filebeat decides to send all lines from that old file. What I would expect is that just the new lines would be sent.
data.title: Registrar does not persist data on all prospected files

Windows Event Log is a custom binary file format, reading which is not currently supported by Filebeat. We should either add this support or create a new beat that allows consuming and processing these logs. 

Migrated from: https://github.com/elastic/logstash-forwarder/issues/485

data.body:
The init script should be modified to execute Filebeat from a service user account to avoid security problems. If there is a bug in Filebeat that allows to take control over the service and it was executed with root privileges, the attacker will have root access in our system.
A possible modification to do this could be:
````
    daemonopts="--user $service_user --pidfile $pidfile"
                  .
                  .
                  .

    touch $pidfile || return 1
    chown $service_user $pidfile || return 1
    chgrp $service_user $pidfile || return 1
    chmod g+w $pidfile || return 1

    daemon $daemonopts $wrapper $wrapperopts -- $agent $args
````

Another modification would be creating a user account when installing Filebeat.
data.title: Execute Filebeat from a service user account to avoid security problems
